Pemimpin IS Tewas di Perbatasan Negaranya, Mengapa Turki Lalai Mendeteksi?
06 Nov 2019, 10:58 by DW
Pekan lalu, Presiden Amerika Serikat (AS), Donald Trump mengumumkan kematian pemimpin Islamic State (IS) , Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, dalam serangan militer AS di wilayah Suriah utara. Sontak, hal ini menuai reaksi positif dari negara-negara Barat.
Namun, di sisi lain berita kematian pemimpin teroris berusia 65 tahun ini justru menimbulkan pertanyaan serius:
Bagaimana mungkin, tidak ada yang mendeteksi keberadaan salah satu teroris paling dicari di dunia itu? Padahal ia menetap hanya beberapa kilometer dari perbatasan Turki?
Pada Selasa (5/11), saudara perempuan al-Baghdadi yang berada sekitar 6 kilometer dari perbatasan Turki, juga telah ditangkap oleh otoritas Turki di dekat kota Azar, Suriah utara.
Pertanyaan lanjutannya, apakah wilayah perbatasan Turki telah menjadi tempat persembunyian bagi para teroris IS dan bagaimana hubungan pemerintah Turki dengan kelompok-kelompok jihadis ini?
Baca juga: Pemimpin ISIS Tewas, Amerika Amankan Ladang Minyak Suriah
Apakah Turki menutup mata?
Seorang jurnalis asal Turki, yang ahli dalam pembahasan terorisme IS, Erk Acarer menyebut, kematian al-Baghdadi di dekat perbatasan Turki, bertolak belakang dengan semangat Turki memberantas terorisme di Suriah utara.
"Melalui operasi militer di Idlib, Suriah, sebanyak 3.000 warga Suriah masuk ke Turki dan pihak berwenang bahkan tidak menyadarinya," ujarnya.
Ia juga menyesalkan kurangnya pengawasan terhadap pihak-pihak yang dapat menimbulkan ancaman bagi Turki, karena dengan mudah masuk ke wilayah negaranya.
Menurut mantan Wakil Kepala Badan Intelijen Nasional Turki, Cevat Ones, pemerintah Turki serius memerangi terorisme dan mendapat dukungan dari masyarakatnya.
Namun, Ones tidak menampik bahwa ada saat-saat ketika pemerintah Turki meremehkan ancaman jihadis. Terutama soal anggapan bahwa perbatasan Turki tidak dikontrol dengan baik sejak perang saudara di Suriah, dimulai pada 2011.
Ia menambahkan banyak teroris memasuki zona perang melalui Turki.
"Ada banyak kritik, dan memang begitu adanya. Perbatasan tidak diamankan – namun kelemahan ini sedang diperkuat,” katanya.
"Turki sedang memerangi teroris," kata Ones, seraya menjelaskan maksud invasi Turki ke Suriah utara, pada Oktober lalu.
Baca juga: Pemimpin ISIS Tewas, Indonesia Waspada Potensi Serangan Balasan
Kelalaian mematikan?
Kematian al-Baghdadi menuai kritik dari oposisi pemerintah yang mengatakan bahwa kecerobohan Turki dalam menangani teroris IS, telah membahayakan warga negaranya.
Ada banyak teror yang dilakukan simpatisan IS sejak tahun 2015, seperti serangan bunuh diri di kota Suruc, di perbatasan Suriah, yang menewaskan 34 orang.
Kemudian ada peristiwa bom bunuh diri yang dilakukan dua teroris, di depan stasiun kereta api di pusat Turki, pada tahun 2015, yang telah menewaskan sekitar 100 orang dan menjadi peristiwa serangan teroris terburuk sepanjang sejarah Turki.
Pada 2016, terjadi serangan teror di bandara Ataturk, Istanbul. Setahun setelahnya, terjadi serangan teror di kelab malam Istanbul pada Malam Tahun Baru 2017.
Padahal menurut seorang pengacara asal Turki, Nuray Ozdogan, serangan teror yang menewaskan sekitar 100 nyawa, bisa dihindari bila ada penyelidikan serius terhadap serangan sebelumnya yang terjadi di Suruc, Turki.
Ada sebanyak 66 laporan dinas rahasia, yang menyebutkan tentang peristiwa bom bunuh diri di Turki.
Sebelumnya, Ozdogan menuntut penyelidikan atas kasus serangan oleh teroris IS di Ankara, Suruc dan Diyarbakir, di Turki ini, namun permohonannya ditolak.
Menurutnya, banyak bukti yang menunjukkan bahwa Turki harus bertindak atas insiden ini. Namun, bukti-bukti dan dokumen tidak pernah ditunjukkan, karena pihak kepolisian dan Lembaga intelijen tidak mengeluarkan informasi apa pun.
Agenda IS masih berlanjut
Belakangan, pihak otoritas Turki lebih mengantisipasi adanya ancaman IS.
Langkah kepolisian menangani IS telah menghiasi laman berita di media-media Turki, termasuk soal penangkapan teroris baru-baru ini di Izmir, Adana dan Istanbul.
Namun, bahaya teror oleh simpatisan IS masih berkembang di banyak kota Turki.
Pada tahun 2015, ratusan simpatisan IS berkumpul di Taman Omerli, di dekat Istanbul, Turki, untuk menghadiri sebuah acara yang secara terbuka menyerukan agenda jihad. Mereka terang-terangan menunjukkan ideologi fundamentalisnya.
Kematian al-Baghdadi memunculkan harapan bahwa Turki akan mengambil langkah tegas memerangi kelompok teroris, seperti IS. Tetapi para ahli mewaspadai ancaman teror IS yang masih akan terus berlanjut, bahkan saat pemimpin kelompok teroris itu telah tewas. (pkp/vlz)

IS Leader Killed at the Border of His Country, Why Does Turkey Ignore Detection?
Nov 6 2019, 10:58 by DW
Last week, the President of the United States (US), Donald Trump, announced the death of the leader of the Islamic State (IS), Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, in a US military attack on northern Syria. Suddenly, this is reaping a positive reaction from Western countries.
However, on the other hand the news of the death of this 65-year-old terrorist leader raises serious questions:
How is it possible that no one has detected the existence of one of the most wanted terrorists in the world? Even though he settled only a few kilometers from the Turkish border?
On Tuesday (5/11), al-Baghdadi's sister, which is about 6 kilometers from the Turkish border, was also captured by Turkish authorities near the northern Syrian city of Azar.
The follow-up question is whether the Turkish border region has become a hiding place for IS terrorists and how is the Turkish government's relationship with these jihadist groups?
Also read: ISIS Leader Killed, America Secures Syria Oil Field
Does Turkey close its eyes?
A journalist from Turkey, who is an expert in the discussion of IS terrorism, Erk Acarer said, the death of al-Baghdadi near the Turkish border, contrasts with Turkey's spirit in eradicating terrorism in northern Syria.
"Through a military operation in Idlib, Syria, as many as 3,000 Syrians entered Turkey and the authorities did not even realize it," he said.
He also deplored the lack of supervision of parties who could pose a threat to Turkey, because it easily entered the territory of his country.
According to former Deputy Head of the Turkish National Intelligence Agency, Cevat Ones, the Turkish government is serious about fighting terrorism and has the support of its people.
However, Ones did not dismiss that there were times when the Turkish government downplayed the threat of jihadists. Especially about the assumption that the Turkish border has not been well controlled since the civil war in Syria, starting in 2011.
He added that many terrorists entered the war zone through Turkey.
"There is a lot of criticism, and indeed it is. The border is not secured - but this weakness is being strengthened," he said.
"Turkey is fighting terrorists," Ones said, explaining the intention of the Turkish invasion of northern Syria last October.
Also read: ISIS Leader Killed, Indonesia Alert Potential for Counterattacks
Deadly negligence?
Al-Baghdadi's death has drawn criticism from the government opposition which says that Turkey's carelessness in dealing with IS terrorists, has endangered its citizens.
There has been a lot of terror carried out by IS sympathizers since 2015, such as a suicide attack in the city of Suruc, on the Syrian border, which killed 34 people.
Then there was the suicide bombing carried out by two terrorists, in front of the train station in central Turkey, in 2015, which killed around 100 people and became the worst terrorist attack event in Turkish history.
In 2016, there was a terror attack at Istanbul's Ataturk airport. A year later, there was a terror attack at the Istanbul nightclub on New Year's Eve 2017.
Yet according to a lawyer from Turkey, Nuray Ozdogan, a terror attack that killed around 100 lives, could be avoided if there was a serious investigation into the previous attack that took place in Suruc, Turkey.
There are 66 secret service reports, which mention suicide bombings in Turkey.
Earlier, Ozdogan demanded an investigation into IS terrorist attacks in Ankara, Suruc and Diyarbakir, in Turkey, but his request was rejected.
According to him, a lot of evidence shows that Turkey must act on this incident. However, evidence and documents were never presented, because the police and intelligence agencies did not release any information.
The IS agenda continues
Later, Turkish authorities anticipated an IS threat.
The move by the police to deal with IS has graced news pages in Turkish media, including the matter of recent terrorist arrests in Izmir, Adana and Istanbul.
However, the danger of terror by IS sympathizers is still developing in many Turkish cities.
In 2015, hundreds of IS sympathizers gathered at Omerli Park, near Istanbul, Turkey, to attend an event that openly called for a jihad agenda. They openly show their fundamentalist ideology.
The death of al-Baghdadi raised hopes that Turkey would take decisive steps to fight terrorist groups, such as IS. But experts are wary of the IS terror threat that will continue, even when the leader of the terrorist group has died. (pkp / vlz)
